services-list.title-list: The steps to buying your home in Spain

details.title: 1. Understanding Your Goals and Preferences
details.description: We begin by getting to know you, your needs, budget, lifestyle, and investment goals. Whether you’re looking for a holiday villa, a permanent residence, or an investment property, we tailor our search to match your exact requirements. Our team has in-depth knowledge of Costa del Sol.

details.title: 2. Property Search and Selection
details.description: Based on your preferences, we present a curated selection of properties that meet your criteria. We search across our own listings as well as through our network of trusted agents and developers, ensuring full market access, not just what’s publicly available. Our focus is on finding the right property, not just any property.

details.title: 3. Property Viewings
details.description: We organize viewing schedules that fit your visit, whether you’re in Spain or traveling from abroad. We accompany you to each viewing, provide honest insights about each property, and highlight both opportunities and potential concerns. If you cannot travel, we can arrange virtual viewings with video tours and live walkthroughs. Transparency and honest advice are at the heart of what we do. You’ll always know exactly what you’re viewing and what to expect.

details.title: 4. Due Diligence and Legal Verification
details.description:
Once you find a property you’re interested in, our legal team steps in to perform a full due diligence check.
This includes verifying:

- Legal ownership and registration (Nota Simple)
- Urban planning compliance
- Outstanding debts, taxes, or community fees
- Building licenses and certificates

With Baruch Real Estate, you benefit from having legal professionals working closely with your agent, ensuring every property is legally sound before you commit.

details.title: 5. Negotiation and Offer Handling
details.description:
We represent your interests during the negotiation phase, aiming to secure the best possible price and terms.
Our experience in the Costa del Sol market allows us to guide you with realistic expectations and solid data on property values.
We handle the communication with the seller’s agent and ensure that every offer is clear, written, and compliant with Spanish law.

details.title: 6. Reservation and Deposit
details.description:
When an offer is accepted, a reservation contract (Contrato de Reserva) is signed and a small deposit is paid to remove the property from the market.
Our legal team ensures the terms protect your interests and that all payments are made safely through secure client accounts.

details.title: 7. Private Purchase Contract (Contrato de Arras)
details.description:
After the reservation, the next step is the private purchase contract.
This legally binding agreement outlines the conditions of the sale, payment schedule, and completion date.
Our legal partners review or draft this document to ensure it fully represents your rights as the buyer.

details.title: 8. Final Signing at the Notary
details.description:
The purchase is completed with the Escritura de Compraventa (title deed) signed before a Spanish notary.
We accompany you to the notary, ensure that all documents are correct, and verify that payment and property transfer are executed safely.
If you are unable to attend in person, we can arrange a power of attorney so that your purchase can be completed remotely.

details.title: 9. Post-Completion Services
details.description:
After completion, we continue to assist with:
• Utility transfers and registrations
• Property insurance
• Tax registration (NIE, IBI, etc.)
• Banking and payment setup

Our goal is to make your transition as seamless as possible, so you can start enjoying your new home right away.

services-list.title: Residency / NIE in Spain
services-list.description:
Everything You Need to Know About Getting a NIE or Residency in Spain

If you plan to buy a property, open a bank account, work, or live in Spain, you’ll need an NIE number (Número de Identidad de Extranjero). This number is essential for almost any official, legal, or financial process in Spain — whether you are a resident or a non-resident property owner.

At Baruch Real Estate, we make it easy. We assist our clients with the NIE application process and can also arrange it on your behalf via Power of Attorney (POA), saving you time, stress, and travel.

details.title: What Is a NIE?
details.description:
The NIE is your foreigner identification number in Spain. It’s issued by the Spanish authorities (Policía Nacional) and used for all administrative and legal matters.

You’ll need an NIE if you plan to:

• Buy or sell property
• Sign at the notary
• Open a Spanish bank account
• Connect utilities (electricity, water, internet)
• Pay taxes in Spain
• Register a car
• Start a business or work legally

The NIE itself is not a residency permit; it’s simply your tax and identification number as a foreigner. However, it’s a first and necessary step if you plan to live, invest, or stay long-term in Spain.

details.title: NIE vs. Residency — What’s the Difference?
details.description:
• NIE (Número de Identidad de Extranjero):
A personal identification number issued to foreigners for tax and legal purposes. You can have an NIE without being a resident.

• Residency (Residencia):
A legal status that allows you to live in Spain for more than 90 days per year. Depending on your nationality, this can be obtained through EU Residency Registration or a Non-Lucrative / Golden Visa application.

Most of our international clients start with the NIE, especially when buying property, and then decide later whether to apply for residency.

details.title: The NIE Application Process
details.description:
Step 1: Determine How You Will Apply
You can apply for a NIE:
1. In person at a Spanish police station (Comisaría de Policía) with a foreigners’ office (Oficina de Extranjería).
2. Through Power of Attorney (POA), we can handle the entire process on your behalf without you needing to travel.

Step 2: Prepare the Required Documents
The documentation typically includes:
• Completed EX-15 application form
• Copy of your passport (and original if applying in person)
• Proof of why you need the NIE (e.g., property purchase, work contract)
• Appointment confirmation (Cita Previa)
• Payment of the NIE tax fee (Tasa 790, Code 012)

If you use Baruch Real Estate’s NIE service, we prepare all required documents and ensure everything is filled in correctly, avoiding the common errors that can delay approval.

details.title: Power of Attorney (POA) Option
details.description:
If you’re outside Spain or prefer not to visit the police station yourself, you can authorize our legal partner to apply for the NIE on your behalf.

This is done through a Power of Attorney (Poder Notarial), which can be signed:
• At a notary in Spain, or
• At a notary in your home country, and then legalized with an Apostille of The Hague.

Once the POA is received, we submit the NIE application and collect the document once issued. This is a fast, secure, and convenient option, ideal for foreign buyers or investors.

details.title: Collecting Your NIE Certificate
details.description:
Once approved, the NIE certificate is issued by the Spanish authorities and contains your name, nationality, and unique NIE number.

We send it directly to you (or your lawyer) securely. The number is permanent and valid for life — you’ll use it for all official transactions in Spain.

details.title: Residency Options in Spain
details.description:
If you plan to live in Spain permanently or for more than 90 days per year, you’ll need to apply for Residency. There are several options depending on your nationality and situation:

EU Citizens:
• Apply for Residency Certificate (Certificado de Registro de Ciudadano de la Unión Europea).
• You’ll need proof of income, health insurance, and a Spanish address.

Non-EU Citizens:
You may qualify for one of the following:
• Non-Lucrative Visa: For individuals who wish to live in Spain without working, supported by sufficient financial means.
• Golden Visa: For those investing €500,000 or more in Spanish property.
• Work or Business Visa: For those employed or self-employed in Spain.

We can connect you with trusted legal partners to assist in choosing and processing the right residency application for your case.

Everything You Need to Know About Taxes in Spain

Whether you’re living in Spain, buying property, or earning income from Spanish sources, understanding the tax system is crucial. Taxes can vary depending on your residency status, type of income, and property ownership.

At Baruch Real Estate, we work with trusted accountants and tax advisors to ensure your taxes are filed correctly, efficiently, and in compliance with Spanish law, giving you peace of mind and avoiding costly mistakes.

details.title: 1. Resident in Spain
details.description:
You are generally considered a resident for tax purposes if you live in Spain for more than 183 days per year or have your main economic interests in the country.

Residents are required to declare:

• Worldwide income
• Property, investments, and assets in Spain and abroad
• Capital gains, dividends, and rental income

details.title: 2. Non-Resident in Spain
details.description:
Non-residents only pay taxes on income and assets located in Spain. This includes:

• Rental income from Spanish property
• Capital gains from the sale of Spanish property
• Spanish-sourced pensions or investments

Understanding your status is crucial because tax rates, deductions, and obligations differ significantly.

details.title: Main Taxes You May Encounter in Spain
details.description:
1. Income Tax (IRPF for residents / IRNR for non-residents)
• Residents (IRPF): Taxed progressively on worldwide income (up to ~47%).
• Non-Residents (IRNR): Flat tax rate on Spanish income (typically 19–24%).

2. Property Taxes
• IBI (Impuesto sobre Bienes Inmuebles): Annual local property tax.
• Plusvalía Municipal: Tax on increase in land value when selling property.
• Wealth Tax (Impuesto sobre el Patrimonio): Applies to residents and sometimes non-residents with high-value assets.

3. Capital Gains Tax
• Applies to gains from the sale of property or investments in Spain.
• Rates differ for residents and non-residents.

4. Inheritance & Gift Tax
• Applicable if you receive property, assets, or money in Spain.
• Rates depend on region and relationship to the donor.

5. VAT / Transfer Tax on Property
• New properties: Subject to VAT (IVA) ~10%
• Resale properties: Subject to Transfer Tax (ITP), varies by region (typically 7–10%).

details.title: Filing a Tax Return in Spain
details.description:
Filing taxes in Spain involves several steps:

1. Collect all documentation: income statements, property details, bank statements, etc.
2. Determine residency status: resident or non-resident.
3. Calculate taxable income: including deductions and allowances.
4. Submit your declaration to the Spanish tax authorities (Agencia Tributaria) within the deadlines.

For most people, working with a local accountant or tax advisor is essential. They can help optimize deductions, avoid penalties, and ensure compliance.

details.title: How Baruch Real Estate Can Help
details.description:
While we are not accountants ourselves, we work with trusted accounting partners who:

• Advise on tax obligations for residents and non-residents
• Handle Spanish tax returns (IRPF/IRNR) and declarations
• Support property-related taxes (IBI, Plusvalía, Transfer Tax)
• Provide guidance on inheritance, gift, and wealth tax

We coordinate with these accountants to ensure that your real estate transactions, income, and property ownership are fully compliant with Spanish tax law, making the process smooth and stress-free.

details.title: Why Work With Our Accountants
details.description:
• Expertise in Spanish tax law for residents and non-residents
• Guidance in your own language
• Optimized filings to avoid overpayment
• Full support for property purchases, sales, and rental income
• Assistance with all tax deadlines and communications with authorities
